profiledesc.creation:
XML finding aid derived from HTML version through cutting and pasting and through folder analysis. 2012
Finding aid encoded by Danielle Emerling, Lilly Library, Indiana University, September 28, 2012

did.head: Summary Information
did.abstract: Consists of further papers of Sir Malcolm Bradbury, 1932–2000 who was knighted in the year 2000 for his services to literature.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in 1932, Bradbury was an academic, writer and critic best known for his novel The History Man.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is in the arrangement as received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers include both extensive material for literary and scholarly works from earlier periods of his life, as well as manuscript drafts, typescripts, correspondence, and copious related material for such later works as The Atlas of Literature (London: De Agostini, 1996), Inside Trading: A Comedy in Three Acts (London: Methuen, 1997), and his final novel To the Hermitage (London: Picador, 2000). The papers also provide additional detailed insight into his life as a teacher, lecturer, and literary critic.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Bradbury, M. mss. III, Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

arrangement.p: The following is a brief listing of the contents or subject of each folder, notebook, file box or accordion file as labeled. Years indicate folders of miscellaneous papers not labeled and may include correspondence. Some materials were formerly filed in hanging folders; loose items were removed to acid–free folders.
